image.altText: a person carrying a baby in the front seat of a car with both not wearing seatbelts

props.synopsis: The NSW government warns if the current trend keeps up more than 100,000 fines will be issued to drivers caught by seatbelt detection cameras over the next 12 months.

title.children: Unrestrained adult and baby among thousands captured by new seatbelt cameras

image.altText: Garma 2024-50

props.synopsis: The federal government will not create a national commission to lead "truth-telling" about First Nations history, departing from its pre-election promise to do so.

title.children: PM discards commitment to set up Makarrata body despite millions in funding

image.altText: A woman stands at the bar with her hands on the beer tap.

props.synopsis: For years, Emily Stanton barely noticed the rundown hotel she regularly drove by in her home town. But after a successful small renovation, she and her husband James decided to take on the biggest project of their lives.

title.children: Outback hotel receives a second life almost four decades after pulling its last beer

image.altText: Wilderness expert Michael Atkinson with snow behind her

props.synopsis: Loyal skiers and snowboarders say the cost of visiting Australia's snowfields is getting to expensive for average-income workers. Here are some reasons why.

title.children: How the price of skiing and snowboarding in Australia compares with the rest of the world

image.altText: A group of people holding a banner that reads 'water justice now'

props.synopsis: Traditional owners from the Murray-Darling Basin say the buying power of $100 million for Aboriginal Water Entitlements has already begun to fall, just eight months after the federal funding was announced.

title.children: Murray-Darling Basin Indigenous leaders say government has 'failed' to deliver water justice

image.altText: Anna Dultseva and her daughter walk alongside Vladimir Putin, holding bouquets.

props.synopsis: A family of Russian sleeper agents flown to Moscow in the biggest East-West prisoner swap since the Cold War were so deep undercover that the children found out they were Russians only after the flight took off, according to the Kremlin.

title.children: Children of Russian sleeper agents believed they were Argentinian until flight home

image.altText: crocodile on river bank

props.synopsis: The tourist from New South Wales was fishing along the banks of a Far North Queensland river when he is believed to have slipped into the water.

title.children: Search for NSW fisherman after suspected crocodile attack near Cooktown

image.altText: a row of four children in school uniform looking at smartphones

props.synopsis: The ABC asked high school students what they thought about social media bans for people under 14 set to be mooted by state governments. Here's what they had to say.

title.children: Teens say social media literacy key to online safety, not age restrictions

props.synopsis: From a cyclist stopping mid-race to hop into a bar to some incredible performances on the track — here are some moments you may have missed overnight in Paris.

title.children: Olympic quick hits: Cyclist stops mid-race to enter a bar, Femke's stunning run, and St Lucia celebrates its new hero

image.altText: Fletcher Sharpe of the Knights is tackled during an NRL match against Penrith

props.synopsis: Newcastle travel to Penrith needing an upset to maintain a realistic chance of playing finals football. Follow live.

title.children: Panthers and Knights going down to the wire in tense battle

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 76' Isaiah Iongi produces a try-saving tackle
70' TRY: Nathan Cleary does it himself and scores
66' PENALTY GOAL: Newcaslte level the scores at 14-14

image.altText: Mabior Chol celebrates after kicking a goal

props.synopsis: Hawthorn has shown why it is a legitimate finals chance with another strong performance against the GWS Giants. Meanwhile, Essendon is looking to keep its finals hopes alive as it hosts Fremantle at the MCG. Follow live.

title.children: Red-hot Hawks on the verge of claiming another big scalp, as Dons seek redemption against Dockers

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Play underway at the MCG between Bombers and Dockers
Another coach drops out of race for West Coast job

image.altText: A woman with dark hair smiling and a man with blond hair and pursed lips

props.synopsis: Kamala Harris's campaign team says Donald Trump is trying to back out of a debate scheduled to run on a rival network.

title.children: Harris, Trump disagree on presidential debate as Trump proposes Fox News event

image.altText: A man picks through broken concrete in a destroyed multi-level building

props.synopsis: Hamas initiates a broad consultation process to select a new leader following the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh.

title.children: Hamas looks for new leader amid Israeli strikes in Gaza and West Bank

image.altText: Adelaide researcher Dr Michael Taylor has found legionella bacteria can live on their own

props.synopsis: Victoria's health authorities confirm two people have died in a legionnaires' disease outbreak in Melbourne and dozens of people are in hospital. A source is yet to be identified.

title.children: Two people confirmed dead in Melbourne's legionnaires' disease outbreak with source still unidentified

image.altText: High density housing with predominantly dark roofs.

props.synopsis: Access to decent housing should be the "Great Australian Right," says a former Victorian Supreme Court justice.

title.children: Australia must treat housing as a human right, says former Victorian Supreme Court judge

image.altText: A graphic of a red up arrow next to a percentage sign, overlaid on a street view of a row of houses.

props.synopsis: Anyone with a home loan right now is likely to be closely watching the Reserve Bank of Australia, which is meeting this week to decide whether it will change the cash rate target. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: Major banks have different forecasts for rate drops — but they agree on the outcome of this week's meeting

image.altText: Two men fight among a crowd of protesters in a town square

props.synopsis: False information spread on social media after a knife attack at a children's dance class sparks violent protests across the UK.

title.children: Police hurt in protests across England sparked by misinformation in wake of stabbing attack

image.altText: Jimmy Barnes and Jane Barnes smile in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: The Australian singer says he's expected to make a full recovery after heading to hospital with "unbearable" pain.

title.children: Jimmy Barnes puts shows on hold after a hip 'twinge' turns into surgery and a six-week recovery

image.altText: Woman looks at piece of fabric on shelf, surrounded by rolls of fabric

props.synopsis: An online marketplace is rehoming vast amounts of excess fabric left unused by Australian fashion brands — and it's good news for small labels and home sewers.

title.children: Designer refashions surplus fabric waste into online store, creating cash flow for small brands

props.synopsis: Eight prisoners, whose crimes included murder, espionage, hacking and fraud, have returned to Russia in the largest prisoner swap between the West and Russia since the Cold War.

title.children: With a hug from Putin, a stark prediction came true as horrified victims watch on

image.altText: Remco Evenepoel is cheered on

props.synopsis: Some fans arrived to the Montmartre climb a full seven hours before the Paris 2024 Olympic Games road race was due to pass. And they had one hell of a day.

title.children: Paris's biggest street party broke out yesterday — and there happened to be some world-class cycling in the middle of it

image.altText: GettyImages-2164650041

props.synopsis: In emotional scenes, Imane Khelif wins her quarterfinal clash in the boxing to assure a medal at the Paris Olympics amid a cloud of misinformation and online trolling.

title.children: Algerian boxer Imane Khelif reduced to tears as she clinches Paris Olympics medal

image.altText: A man rides a snowskate on the snow with blue sky and light clouds behind

props.synopsis: Snowskating is banned for public at Australia's major alpine resorts, but advocates are working to change this as the sport grows in popularity around the world.

title.children: Part ski, part skateboard, could this be Australia's next big winter sport?

image.altText: Woman holding phone infront of another man

props.synopsis: Two different communities living 15,000 kilometres apart have found a way to heal together after experiencing severe natural disasters.

title.children: From Brazil to the WA outback, how two remote communities found strength after natural disasters

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: So you're back to give this quiz thing another go? Come on then, I promise I won't judge … much.

title.children: Still believe you can beat me at my own game? It's time to play … HARD!

image.altText: A takeaway pasta dish still in its box

props.synopsis: Originally introduced in the country by US chain Outback Steakhouse, experts say the dish's meteoric rise proves there are big export opportunities in South Korea for "truly authentic" Aussie products.

title.children: How a pasta dish named after an Australian inland city took South Korea by storm

image.altText: 3d rendering of abstract geometric shapes and cube blocks. Neon lights, blue and pink colors.

props.synopsis: Scientists are harnessing the Tetris effect, a phenomenon described by people who play the classic 1980s video puzzle game, to help unlock dreams and treat post traumatic stress disorder.

title.children: Love playing Tetris? Its effects on your brain are surprisingly profound

image.altText: Bright coloured portraits of three LGBTQIA+ advocates from South-East Asia.

props.synopsis: Thailand's reputation as a "queer paradise" may do more than just line the pockets of wedding vendors.

title.children: Thailand's 'pink baht' boom set to benefit more than just wedding venues

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus

props.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus explains the pressure she felt coming into the Paris Olympics, as Australia added three more medals to its tally in the pool.

title.children: 'I felt so much pressure': Titmus opens up after claiming heroic 800m silver behind American legend

props.synopsis: As more Australians opt in to share housing, photographer Aishah Kenton explores how the concept is changing from a home for now to a forever home.

title.children: The share house used to be home for a time. These roommates are changing that

image.altText: Katie Ledecky leans back in the pool

props.synopsis: Katie Ledecky fourth-straight victory in the 800m has assured her Olympics immortality — but who is next in line to create greatness in the pool?

title.children: In achieving what only one other woman has ever done, Katie Ledecky has cemented her spot as an Olympics immortal

image.altText: Two teenage girls lying on a bed with their hair draped over the side while looking at their phones.

props.synopsis: Teenage girls are the main accelerators of how language changes and evolves. It's a reminder that the most influential people in our society aren't always the most obvious.

title.children: The way teenage girls speak is often derided, but they are in fact our linguistic trailblazers

image.altText: The British fantasy author Samantha Shannon, a woman in her early 30s with brunette hair and big eyes, smiling

props.synopsis: Samantha Shannon landed a six-figure publishing deal at the tender age of 20. Her first book, The Bone Season, was a huge hit. So why did she go and rewrite it?

title.children: Samantha's version: Why a bestselling British fantasy author is rewriting her old books

image.altText: A photo taken from over the top of the King and Queen showing off their crowns

props.synopsis: Days after he lost his job, the former assistant minister for a republic called the movement to offer reassurance.

title.children: The PM has torpedoed the republic portfolio, but the movement says it understands why
